subject: Learning
title: Attachment and Learning Readiness
description: A fast breakdown of Attachment and Learning Readiness for builders.

hook.text: A securely attached toddler explores a new room confidently. An insecurely attached one clings and won't let go.

buildup.text: John Bowlby's attachment theory shows that secure relationships with caregivers create a safe base for exploration.

discovery.text: Securely attached children explore more, ask more questions, and persist longerâ€”all prerequisites for learning.

twist.text: Insecure attachment doesn't mean the child can't learn. But their energy goes to managing anxiety, not exploring.

climax.text: Teachers who form warm, consistent bonds with students can become secondary attachment figuresâ€”restoring the safe base.

punchline.text: Security first, learning second. A safe child is a curious child.

quiz.question: How does secure attachment support learning?
options: It creates a safe base for exploration, curiosity, and persistence
Attachment has no effect on learning ability
Insecurely attached children always learn faster
